statutorily recognised by the legislature. Section 26 of the Act recognizes the finality of
an arbitral award by providing that an award made by the arbitral tribunal shall be final
and binding on the parties to the arbitration agreement. The limited space that has been
allowed for the intervention by Courts in relation to a domestic arbitral award is through
(a) Section 32 in Part VII of the Act which lays down an exhaustive set of grounds in terms
of which an award may be set aside, and (b) the provisions of Section 31. I shall advert to
these provisions in detail later in this judgment.
